text: Really nice article <@UT9JX4C5C> <https://www.animalz.co/blog/technical-content/> - This is great advice. But as you say, developers have no time to write, so I write for them (I'm a former technical writer so I at least understand the content). My question is, *would you change any of this if you're trying to market a service rather than a product?* I work for a VC that is also kind of like an agency (lends out developers). We want to A) Attract new talent and B) Get startups to use our dev expertise. I try to write about developer learnings in the field, but the topics are a bit scatter-gun right now....

attachments.title: Technical Content: A Strategy Blueprint for SaaS Companies - Animalz
attachments.text: Learn how to create authentic, effective content marketing for technical products.
attachments.fallback: Animalz: Technical Content: A Strategy Blueprint for SaaS Companies - Animalz

elements.text: Really nice article
- This is great advice. But as you say, developers have no time to write, so I write for them (I'm a former technical writer so I at least understand the content). My question is,
would you change any of this if you're trying to market a service rather than a product?

I work for a VC that is also kind of like an agency (lends out developers). We want to A) Attract new talent and B) Get startups to use our dev expertise. I try to write about developer learnings in the field, but the topics are a bit scatter-gun right now....

text: I would also point out that not all devs are native English speakers and some hate writing English (none of the devs I work with are native speakers). It's hard enough getting them to document their APIs let alone write articles)

elements.text: I would also point out that not all devs are native English speakers and some hate writing English (none of the devs I work with are native speakers). It's hard enough getting them to document their APIs let alone write articles)

text:
Does anyone have a strategy / best practice for taking shorter press-release style blog posts and doing something better with them?

For example, we have a couple of blog posts for awards we've won. These are not part of the content strategy and get minimal views, but there is brand value to send people there every now and again.

elements.text:
Does anyone have a strategy / best practice for taking shorter press-release style blog posts and doing something better with them?

For example, we have a couple of blog posts for awards we've won. These are not part of the content strategy and get minimal views, but there is brand value to send people there every now and again.

text: I tend to pull those together into say one longer Awards page.

elements.text: I tend to pull those together into say one longer Awards page.

text: We had a similar thing with Podcasts - the pages for each episode didn't get much in terms of SEO traffic so we made a single Podcasts page and then just updated that each week.

elements.text: We had a similar thing with Podcasts - the pages for each episode didn't get much in terms of SEO traffic so we made a single Podcasts page and then just updated that each week.

text: I have a trello card for this :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I have a trello card for this

text: Ditto to Michael - we look at pulling logos from the awards and adding them to homepage, have awards as a section or page on the website, maybe including relevant awards in headers for social media. also experimented with mentioning them in copy or visuals with advertising - small sample size but no results there.

elements.text: Ditto to Michael - we look at pulling logos from the awards and adding them to homepage, have awards as a section or page on the website, maybe including relevant awards in headers for social media. also experimented with mentioning them in copy or visuals with advertising - small sample size but no results there.

text: Seems like the thing to do them. I'm waiting for dev resource to make our press/awards page go live.

elements.text: Seems like the thing to do them. I'm waiting for dev resource to make our press/awards page go live.

text: Thanks, folks.

elements.text: Thanks, folks.

text: I love converting press releases, especially those announcing an award into a larger blog when it works. The biggest barrier I've run into is the awarding body having a pretty strict media kit full of things we either can't say or have to very specifically say. But if that isn't a factor, I like to dive into what the award stands for and the methodology for how we were awarded. For instance, we were awarded  for a a seasonal hiring program, so I just broke down the criteria for winning the award (increased brand awareness, increased quality conversions, etc.) and wrote a blog highlighted the tools, even customer quotes, that painted a picture of how we can help people build seasonal hiring programs. Those pieces are always so positive and fun to write. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I love converting press releases, especially those announcing an award into a larger blog when it works. The biggest barrier I've run into is the awarding body having a pretty strict media kit full of things we either can't say or have to very specifically say. Those pieces are always so positive and fun to write.

text: Hey! Does anyone here know of any newsletter that’s solely focused on relationship building with its audience and has gained a lot from this approach? Please let me know if I’m not clear with my question or drop me a DM/comment if you know someone. :slightly_smiling_face: Thanks!

elements.text: Hey! Does anyone here know of any newsletter that’s solely focused on relationship building with its audience and has gained a lot from this approach? Please let me know if I’m not clear with my question or drop me a DM/comment if you know someone.
Thanks!

text:
Two people that immediately come to mind are Hiten Shah (Product Habits) and Anne Laure Le Cunff.

Shah has built an audience with Product Habits and (I believe) leverages it for surveys (most recently around Zoom) which he then turns into high-traffic content. E.g. the remote work report.

Anne Laure rapidly grew her newsletter and this may have helped her reach recent profitability goals. It also helped her build a Telegram community around running newsletters.

I'm not sure if those are _solely_ focused on relationship building, but they came to mind :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Thank you so much for them with me, Laura. Any chance these results you’re sharing are documented/published somewhere? Or Shah and Anne talk about them somewhere even if it’s social?

text: Hey all -- has anyone here done a Product Hunt launch before? I'd love your tips / lessons learned as I plan to launch my newsletter about remote work, Remotely Inclined (<https://remotelyinclined.substack.com/>), on PH!

elements.text: Hey all -- has anyone here done a Product Hunt launch before? I'd love your tips / lessons learned as I plan to launch my newsletter about remote work, Remotely Inclined (
), on PH!

text:
I have, although it was eons ago for a project that's now dead. It got some good traction though and lots of sign ups. <https://www.producthunt.com/posts/songs-to-dance-to>
My main piece of advice would be to not post it yourself but find someone who is an active hunter to post it for you, it's easier to get traction that way. And there's a delicate balance between leveraging your community/network and spamming upvotes. But if you build your community pre-launch and then just send out a note saying, "i'm on PH" instead of "vote for me on PH" that should walk that line nicely

text:
Yeah, I only know what I commented from following them. They both work in public, but you may have to do some wading to find the info. 

Anne Laure has talked about it in social, spec Twitter. I think I remember seeing a recent post about a MRR goal. 

Some of what I said about Hiten I pieced together from being on his newsletter for over a year.  But check out his podcast (startup chat, there are over 500 episodes), his product habits website, and try a filtered search of his Twitter feed for what you're looking for.

text:
I have, and I agree with Jessie. Spend time to find a Hunter to post the product on your behalf.
Also, getting upvotes steadily is important if you want to make to the top products of the day.
About the post itself:
1. Make the thumbnail eye-catching (good design/colors)
2. Add a video that shows what your product; in your case, what the email looks like on desktop/mobile + how to sign up
3. Have a good tagline (the top benefit that someone will subscribing to your newsletter will get) to increase clicks and upvotes
